Notes: Open cluster in Auriga. Gray area was elusive, only visible with averted vision
Very faint--have to use averted vision to see anything but the core.  M32 looks like a star
Much brighter than in binoculars - this part of the sky is pretty bright because of the moon and a football game.
A: bigger, light orange. B: smaller, light blue.
Seems like a spiral of stars going in; faintest hint of nebulosity in the center (Didn't know about the name until after writing this description!)
Can barely make out a ring with averted vision -- else just a light blur.
Nice triangular-shaped open cluster. Stars are very crisp and clear and bright.
Very faint, with averted vision seems like a speckle of stars.
Looks like 73 to me.
Primary is a light orange. Secondary is blue (rather deep blue for a star); much fainter. Nice double!
White/pale blue. Looks like a big star, but not as bright.
Supposedly a triple star.  Yes, in finderscope this appears as 3 stars clumped together. :)
Double star. Secondary is very faint, just outside the bright sparkle of the primary. Can see hints of the diffractions patterns due to the spider.
Kind of a pear shape of faint nebulosity - slightly sparkly.
Can see separation between primary and secondary, but lots of noise around the stars. This is a 6-star system, I believe.
No nebulosity, but very sharp, bright stars.
Can't tell which of the close pair is primary; equal brightness. Both are white. Note: if I had better luck and a higher magnification, should be a triple star.
Smaller than I expected. Lots more stars (not shown) with averted vision. General penagon shape. Shaded ovals show areas with many smaller dimmer stars.
Light orange color. Really stands out.
Two brigher stars in a cluster, then sort of a hexagonal grid. Then grayer area that resolves to lots of fain stars with averted vision.
Nebulosity is brightest near the trapezium (see 4 stars) and the row of 3. Also some about tthe star farther down (M43). Very pretty.
Looks like a Christmas tree!
Double. Both appear pale orange.
Both appear bright orange. Nicely separated.
Bright core, with averted vision, a hint of resolving some stars. Seems generally rather gray.
Both bright white.
Bright white disk. Can see 2 main bands and 2 fainter ones at the top and bottom. Closest moon seems to have moved farther from Jupiter after 15 min.
Found this pretty fast today - aimed the red dot finder where I thought it would be, and there it was in the scope!
Very cool - I like the two pairs of doubles in the view. :)
A: white, maybe a hint of blue. B: very pale orange. Pretty double, tricky to find in LP skies.
Both stars are white. Easily split even at 30x.
Hints of more (much fainter) stars with averted vision. Stars are well spread out.
Lots of nebulosity around the primary. Secondary is faint but distinct pin prick.
Lots of very bright white stars. Fairly spread out.
Just a white dot. Other stars for reference. A: 66 CnC, B: 63 CnC
All stars are white, approx same brightness. Sky is washed out here, so contrast could be better. Somewhat faint.
No color in stars.
Beautiful heart-shaped open cluster. Seems to have a small concentration of stars in center right.
Lots of bright stars. I would name this the "Yoshi Cluster". Can easily be seen in 9x50 finderscope.
Primary is yellow, secondary appears dim orange
Looks like an upside down palm tree.
Looks like 71 to me. Lighter stars drawn here are only visible with averted vision.
Long and thin, just a fuzz, no more detail. A little larger, wider with averted vision.
Center much brigher than the rest, although entire galaxy disappears without averted vision.
Brighter in the center. Can't resolve any stars. Whole thing is fairly bright. No averted vision needed.
Looks like a hexagon with a heart on top. Many more stars not drawn.
Concentrated stars at the center. Almost seems like a hint of nebulosity. One bright star.

A: M66 - seems the brightest. Bright core, roundish. B: M65 - slightly dimmer and more eccentric. Also bright core. C: NGC 3628 - looks edge-on. Much fainter, only visible with averted vision. No core.
Clearly two galaxies, with brighter cores.  Appear face-on. Slight separation betwen them. Hint that they may be connected at the top.
Nice snake-shaped sequence of stars in the center.
Very large, spread out cluster. Stars all very bright.
Some concentrations of very faint stars.
Somewhere between a C and a 3. :)
No strong concentration. General pentagon shape. Relatively faint stars.
All stars are white. Nice triple! Second and third stars seem equal in brightness. Cleanly split.
Circular. Brighter center. Looks like a star at lower magnification. Took four attempts to find this!
Looks like an inchworm. Direction a little hard to determine accurately since near zenith and scope is slipping a little.
Nice little globular cluster. Can't resolve any stars. Center is brighter.
Looks like a nice hat. Stars were relatively faint.
Both stars are white. Secondary is fainter, just a pinpoint of light.
Both stars are white. Compared to iota Bootes, these are a little closer, and secondary is brighter.
Can see the coathanger with some effort. Stars are not the same brightness; some on the handle require averted vision to see.

Drawn slightly larger than actually appears in the view. Two bands are obvious, a third, polar band is visible for certain instants of time. Bands are light brown. Supposedly should see the shadow of Io, but no luck.
Very bright, can't use high power since telescope not cooled. Can see that it's gibbous.
Very large and bright. Generally spherical, but appears to have a few chains of stars coming out on the sides.
Doubles not cleanly split, especially epsilon1. However can see two pinpricks for epsilon2.
Quick sketch of the edge of the moon as it was getting covered by a cloud.
Primary star looks a little yellower and seconary is whiter. Easily split. Could see two points with a 25mm eyepiece.
Two great bands. Can see some variability in thickness of the biggest one. Higher band seems broken into two spots.
Moon closest to Jupiter has been moving up and away (SW). Can see 3 bands clearly, hints of a fourth.

#id: 20180601-01-polaris 2018-06-01  Bellevue at home  Omni XLT 150  G 4 Polaris 11:01 5mm 150x  Secondary star is easily separated, but much dimmer. Compass directions are approximate based on the location of the diamond ring in the finderscope. 20180601-01-polaris

Notes: No detail, just a white gibbous disc. Can see some chromatic abberation -- top is red, bottom is violet.
Just a gray patch, slightly brighter in the center
Surprisingly clear, given that I was looking through a cloud! Can see two large bands, bottom band looks darker, and another faint band near the top.
Secondary star is easily separated, but much dimmer. Compass directions are approximate based on the location of the diamond ring in the finderscope.
Moons 1,4 are the brightest, 3 next, 4 is dimmest. All perfectly in a line. Can see different darknesses within the bands.
Small cluster of 7 brighter stars, with a few more dim ones. Not much concentration, rather sparse. Other stars outside this view are much brighter.
Nice clear gibbous shape. Can see the dark side in shadow.
Jupiter visible through the clouds, bands still visible.
Nice bright stars. All white. Classic.
LP is bad enough tthat this is just a fuzzy with direct vision. But averted vision gives lots of stars and detail. Amazing!
(Compared to M 5) Much fainter. Stars seem more distinct, not as dense.
Fairly bright ring. Inside the ring might be slightly brighter than outside.
Super bright! Can see two main bands and part of a third.
Beige color. Outside of rings are darker. Hint of the Cassini division.
M23 - Loose stars, not really any brighter in the center. Vesta - bright (brighter than the rest of the stars), slightly yellow color. Easily seen in the 9x50 finderscope, but not naked eye.
Can see darker shades (twilight?) towards the edge of the lit side.
Somewhat dim. Fairly large. Easy to see lots of stars. Center is brighter, seems like a line of stars through the center.
Quite faint. Mostly need averted vision to see anything. Slightly brighter core. Can resolve some stars.

Wow. This is like the Pleiades -- lots of bright stars scattered, no concentration. Need bigger FOV to fully take this in! Only brighter stars drawn here. Background looks like the milky way through binoculars.
Small globular. Can't resolve any stars. Brighter in the center.
Very big, bright. Can resolve lots of stars. Surrounded by a nice ring of stars. Lots more fainter stars, but covered in a cloud before could fill in a more detailed sketch.
Nice open cluster of stars. Lots of nebulosity, esp in binoculars. Was going to pack things up until I saw this.
Drawn larger.  Can see the terminator is a shade darker than the lit side.
Very bright. Outer part of rings are dimmer. Almost seems like a belt across saturn. Can see the shadow of the rings on Saturn.  T: Titan. R: Rhea. I: Iapetus
Crips open cluster. Seems to have a small concentration of stars in the bottom middle of the "W"
Hard to tell where the boundary of this cluster is. Nice pentagon in the middle. Curious if there would be lots more stars in a darker sky; I don't see many really faint ones.
Slight concentration of stars near the center.
Quite bright; core is the brightest. Can't resolve any stars distinctly, but it has a speckled appearance. With averted vision.  Can see some stars at the edge.
Super bright orange. Very large. Not much detail.  Can see a whiter area on the N pole and a slightly darker area towards the south.

A: visually looks like it might be a planetary nebula. Seems brighter and with averted vision sometimes see a small disc around it.  B: position seems more correct, but looks sharper, more star-like. [Yes, confirmed with Stellarium that A is the PN.]
Lots of stars. No concentration. Very pretty. :)
Very spread out; stars have very different magnitudes
Lots of fairly faint stars -- too many to draw accurately. At lower powers this looks like a faint globular.
Very dim. Stars resolve with averted vision, with direct vision it's just a lighter gray patch
Very faint gray patch. Hint of some stars with averted vision.  Have to shake the telescope to find this. Slight brighter in the core.
Mostly just a faint smudge. Can see hints of stars with averted vision.
Very small, bright core. However with averted vision can see it's quite large and diffuse at the edges. I like this one! :)
Both stars are bright white. Primary is quite bright. Easy split.
Brighter core. Only the faintest hint of any stars with averted vision; mostly a smudge.
Nice open cluster; a few bright stars and many very faint ones. Some slight nebulosity visible next to the star on the left.  Not as impressive as at the darker site, but still pretty cool.
Very open cluster. Not too many stars.
Looks mostly like an open cluster. Possibly the faintest hint of nebulosity around the double star ear the center; the area is just slightly brighter.
Very faint. Core is not much brighter than the edges. Can see some stars with averted vision. Many faint stars everywhere in the field; too many to sketch
Modestly bright blurry patch. A bit squarish with a piece taken out on the side. Very nice. :)
Very faint blur. Can't resolve any stars. hard to see, even after aming right at it.
Nice geometric patterns white stars well-spaced.
Very small crescent. Very blurry. Can only be seen with the telescope; can't even see with 10x50 finder. Mercery is close to the moon tonight. I used that to locate it.
